title: Just Because ChatBots Can’t Think Doesn’t Mean They Can’t Lie

last_post.content:
Better people than me might be able to suppress a chuckle upon discovering that on the very same blog, Professor Cowen recently argued that Francis Bacon was a vehement opponent of the printing press — based on quotations that Bacon never wrote and which appear to have been generated by ChatGPT.

I don't know his GRE scores so I can't comment on their external validity, but given what I do know I can assure you that he's overpaid.

https://www.thenation.com/article/culture/internet-archive-publishers-lawsuit-chatbot/

As I say in The Gutenberg Parenthesis: Content is a commodity.
AI-written content isn’t the web’s future. It’s already here. https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/05/05/ai-spam-websites-books-chatgpt/

Gentle reminder: there are many blind and partially sighted users on the fediverse, and alt text is important for accessibility. It's becoming more and more commonplace that people won't boost toots with media that's either undescribed or lacking in a call for help with the alt text.

I have a guide here on how to write alt text, a bot you can follow if you keep forgetting, and options for asking for help with alt text:

https://mastodon.art/@Curator/109279035107793247

Please, alt-text your media. :bear_hugs:

You can now download my free textbook using the download menu button as a 500 page (!) pdf file, or an epub version https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/. But: I consider the html book the main version (with interactive assignments, gifs, shiny apps) so if the pdf is not 100% correct, I probably won't fix it.

Right now Graduate Workers at the University of Michigan are on strike trying to get a living wage for the work that they do. This time trans healthcare is also under debate as many grad workers can not access the care that they need.

When asked to improve access to trans healthcare, the University of Michigan said they are "not interested in doing that". After being told how desperately their students need this care, and how they are suffering, they responded with indifference and sighed with relief when the next topic was introduced.

Please boost this, the University is trying to hide behind a progressive facade while rejecting a living wage and trans care.

#transrights #uofm #goblue #trans

Edit: Please also consider donating to their strike fund. The University has stopped paying graduate workers, including some that were not on strike https://givebutter.com/GEOStrikeFund

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)
Great story from the @RogueAmoeba blog about a meeting with Adam Curry, Eddie Cue, and Steve Jobs that may have saved Audio Hijack.

title: Catch-23: The New C Standard Sets the World on Fire - ACM Queue

last_post.content:
This parody of Jefferson Airplane's classic song "White Rabbit" is about programming psychedelia—undefined behavior in C.

One flag makes it faster

and one flag makes it small

and the deprecated -Wchkp

doesn't do anything at all.

Go ask Lattner

if we should use -Wall.

And if you go comparing pointers

across segments you're going to fall.

That's how a hookah-smoking working group

has standardized it all.

Go ask Lattner

did they make the right call?

When your loops and expressions

get up from where you said they go

and Clang just had some kind of warning

and Valgrind is moving slow,

go ask Lattner;

I hope he'll know.

When the logic of -O3

is calling your code dead

and the main() task is writing backwards

while the workers race ahead,

remember what the Helgrind said:

Lock your thread. Lock your thread.

https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=3588242

title: DINOv2: Learning Robust Visual Features without Supervision

last_post.content:
Meta Research "Dino v2" model: https://ai.facebook.com/blog/dino-v2-computer-vision-self-supervised-learning/

Lots of interesting stuff in here, but one of my favorite bits is that their model internalized enough information about the “semantic parts” of objects it recognizes, that it can correlate them across widely-varying images.

Definitely try the demos (linked from the blog post).

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.07193

"The lesson of Britain is that the long-expected crisis that will act as a moment of reset never arrives. In the chaos around #NLP, I went back and re-read the beautiful article by Lawrence Barsalou on the function of language in human cognition.

Barsalou argues that language evolved in humans to support coordinated action. Archival function of language is secondary. He highlights that #CognitiveScience #Linguistics has largely studied the secondary function and making minimal advances on the the primary.

#AI, #ML, #NLP have a similar bias.

Paper: https://barsaloulab.org/Online_Articles/1999-Barsalou-DP-situated_comprehension.pdf

On a modern yacht in the middle of the ocean with a broken rudder, send out a call for help, then out of the misty past THIS, the Götheborg out of Sweden, comes to rescues you ... Wow!

[The arrival of the Götheborg on the scene was rapid and surprising, as we did not expect to see a merchant ship from the East India Company of the XVIII century. This moment was very strange, and we wondered if we were dreaming. Where were we? What time period was it?]

What a beautiful ship 😍

Story: https://www.gotheborg.se/news/rescue-of-sailing-boat/

#SailingShip #Yacht #Ocean #History

So, I've just published my first "public" blog post, on code vs. low-code in healthcare analytics. This is an opinionated article, and I'd love to hear other views. I feel strongly that the only right direction for NHS organisations is to grab hold of open-source, and do as much as possible in the public domain, using free vanilla tools like #rstats, #python, and #git. Do you agree?
https://smithdata.co.uk/blog/posts/2023-05-05/code-vs-low-code
